doc.field: Inscribed oracle from Klaros (re-inscribed in imperial period)
Syedrans instructed by the god to set up a statue of Ares being flogged by Hermes and Justice to ward off pirates.
Inscribed oracle from Klaros (re-inscribed in imperial period)
Prophecy of a war with pirates that presumably took place.
Decree of Nagidos granting territory and isopoliteia to Arsinoe, as copied in a letter of Thraseas to Arsinoe
Nagidos grants public land to settlers of Arsinoe at request of Thraseas.
Decree of Nagidos granting territory and isopoliteia to Arsinoe, as copied in a letter of Thraseas to Arsinoe
People of Arsinoe to pay the same honours to Ptolemy and Arsinoe.
Decree of Nagidos granting territory and isopoliteia to Arsinoe, as copied in a letter of Thraseas to Arsinoe
People of Arsinoe to pay the taxes from their own means.
Decree of Nagidos granting territory and isopoliteia to Arsinoe, as copied in a letter of Thraseas to Arsinoe
Decree of Nagidos granting territory and isopoliteia to Arsinoe, as copied in a letter of Thraseas to Arsinoe
Fines for disputing the land arrangements of the decree, 10,000 drachmas for an archon, and 1,000 drachmas for a speaker.
Decree of Nagidos granting territory and isopoliteia to Arsinoe, as copied in a letter of Thraseas to Arsinoe
Arrangments for disputes and reparation payments between Nagideans and Arsinoans.

Decree of Rhodes on obtaining naval support
Eudemos asked to fulfill the promised gifts to the city to its naval power, presumably ships and money.

Honorific decrees of Byzantion for Eudemos son of Nikon
Eudemos to have the choice of being included in the hekatostos/hekatoste, a 1/100 (1%) tax.

Private honorific statue-base for Hermias set up by king Philipp I of Syria
Private honorific statue-base for Hermias set up by king Philipp I of Syria
Mention of Hermias possessing a necklace (maniakes) worth 100 chrusoi, perhaps as a sort of court rank.

List of priests of the temple of Zeus

Marks on a marble block with a relief of two women on mules and four standing women

Dedication to Hermes, Herakles and Antiochos III the Great by Ptolemaios son of Thraseas
Fragment of a letter of Antiochos III on the misbehaviour of billeting soldiers, and civic obligations?
Mention of the oppression of the city by troops, when it had been exempt from billeting since the time of Alexander the Great, probably as a background to a grant of remission from such obligations.

Letters and edict of Octavian to Rhosos on the honours for Seleukos of Rhosos
Seleukos' military service with the Romans.
Letters and edict of Octavian to Rhosos on the honours for Seleukos of Rhosos
Exemption from taxation and military obligations, billeting obligations, and on customs-dues.
Letters and edict of Octavian to Rhosos on the honours for Seleukos of Rhosos
Fine of 100,000 sestertii for anyone or any community that hinders Seleukos' enjoyment of these privileges.
Letters and edict of Octavian to Rhosos on the honours for Seleukos of Rhosos
